title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One answer is earned for a correct description.
descriptions: The response does not provide any of the following descriptions of a primate city.
The response provides one of the following descriptions of a primate city.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description of a similarity and one point is earned for a correct description of a difference.
descriptions: The response does not demonstrate either of the following:
The response demonstrates ONE of the following:
The response demonstrates BOTH of the following:

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description.
descriptions: The response does not correctly describe any ways in which primate cities are important within their countries.
The response correctly describes ONE of the following ways in which primate cities are important within their countries.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct explanation.
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain any of the following reasons why the United States does not have a primate city.
The response correctly explains ONE of the following reasons why the United States does not have a primate city.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct explanation.
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain any of the following reasons why having a primate city can negatively impact the economic development of a country.
The response correctly explains ONE of the following reasons why having a primate city can negatively impact the economic development of a country.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct explanation.
descriptions:
The answer does not provide the following explanation of why primate cities may not comply with the rank-size rule.

· According to the rank-size rule, the population of the second largest city in an urban system is equal to the largest city divided by two, the population of the third largest city is equal to the largest city divided by three, etc. The rank-size rule is most applicable to countries in which cities are evenly distributed, whereas primate cities indicate an uneven distribution.

The answer provides the following explanation of why primate cities may not comply with the rank-size rule.

· According to the rank-size rule, the population of the second largest city in an urban system is equal to the largest city divided by two, the population of the third largest city is equal to the largest city divided by three, etc. The rank-size rule is most applicable to countries in which cities are evenly distributed, whereas primate cities indicate an uneven distribution.
